Map_of_USA_States_with_names_white.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Map_of_USA_States_with_names_white.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_USA_States_with_names_white.svg "Enlarge")

Map of the United States with names and borders of states

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/US_states_by_date_of_statehood3.gif/350px-
US_states_by_date_of_statehood3.gif)](/wiki/File:US_states_by_date_of_statehood3.gif)

[](/wiki/File:US_states_by_date_of_statehood3.gif "Enlarge")

The order in which the original 13 states ratified the 1787 Constitution, then
the order in which the others were admitted to the union

A [state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") of the [United States of
America](/wiki/United_States "United States") is one of the 50 [constituent
entities](/wiki/Constituent_state "Constituent state") that shares its
[sovereignty](/wiki/Sovereignty "Sovereignty") with the [federal
government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government
of the United States"). [Americans](/wiki/Americans "Americans") are
[citizens](/wiki/Citizenship_in_the_United_States "Citizenship in the United
States") of both the [federal republic](/wiki/Federal_republic "Federal
republic") and of the state in which they [reside](/wiki/Domicile_\(law\)
"Domicile \(law\)"), due to the shared sovereignty between each state and the
federal government.[1] [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky"),
[Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts"),
[Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"), and
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia") use the [term](/wiki/Nomenclature
"Nomenclature") _[commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_\(U.S._state\)
"Commonwealth \(U.S. state\)")_ rather than _state_ in their full official
names.

States are the primary [subdivisions](/wiki/Administrative_division
"Administrative division") of the United States and possess a number of powers
and rights under the [United States
Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution"),
such as regulating intrastate commerce, running
[elections](/wiki/Elections_in_the_United_States "Elections in the United
States"), creating [local
governments](/wiki/Local_government_in_the_United_States "Local government in
the United States"), and ratifying [constitutional
amendments](/wiki/Constitutional_amendment#United_States "Constitutional
amendment"). Each state has its own
[constitution](/wiki/State_constitution_\(United_States\) "State constitution
\(United States\)") grounded in [republican
principles](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism in the
United States"), and [government](/wiki/State_government_\(United_States\)
"State government \(United States\)") consisting of
[executive](/wiki/Governor_\(United_States\) "Governor \(United States\)"),
[legislative](/wiki/State_legislature_\(United_States\) "State legislature
\(United States\)"), and [judicial](/wiki/State_court_\(United_States\) "State
court \(United States\)") branches.[2]

All states and their residents are represented in the federal
[Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"), a
[bicameral](/wiki/Bicameral "Bicameral") legislature consisting of the
[Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") and the [House of
Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives"). Each state is represented by two Senators, while
Representatives are
[distributed](/wiki/United_States_congressional_apportionment "United States
congressional apportionment") among the states in proportion to the most
recent [constitutionally](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
Constitution") mandated decennial [census](/wiki/United_States_Census "United
States Census").[3] Additionally, each state is entitled to select a number of
electors to vote in the [Electoral
College](/wiki/Electoral_College_\(United_States\) "Electoral College \(United
States\)"), the body that elects the [President of the United
States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States"), equal to the total of Representatives and Senators in Congress from
that state.[4]

[Article IV](/wiki/Article_Four_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article
Four of the United States Constitution"), Section 3, Clause 1 of the
Constitution grants to Congress the authority to
[admit](/wiki/Admission_to_the_Union "Admission to the Union") new states into
the Union. Since the establishment of the United States in 1776, the number of
states has expanded from [the original 13](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen
Colonies") to 50. Each new state has been admitted on an [equal
footing](/wiki/Equal_footing "Equal footing") with the existing states.[5]

The following table is a list of all 50 states and their respective dates of
statehood. The first 13 became states in July 1776 upon agreeing to the
[United States Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence"), and each joined the first Union of states
between 1777 and 1781, upon ratifying the [Articles of
Confederation](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation"),
its first constitution.[6] (A separate table is included below showing AoC
ratification dates.) These states are presented in the order in which each
[ratified](/wiki/Article_Seven_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article
Seven of the United States Constitution") the 1787 Constitution, thus joining
the present federal Union of states. The date of admission listed for each
subsequent state is the official date set by Act of Congress.[a]

## Articles of Confederation ratification
dates[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._states_by_date_of_admission_to_the_Union&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Articles of Confederation ratification dates")]

The [Second Continental Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second
Continental Congress") approved the [Articles of
Confederation](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation")
for ratification by the individual states on November 15, 1777. The Articles
of Confederation [came into force](/wiki/Coming_into_force "Coming into
force") on March 1, 1781, after being ratified by all 13 states. On March 4,
1789, the general government under the Articles was replaced with the [federal
government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government
of the United States") under the present
[Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
Constitution").[43]

  * [Enabling Act of 1802](/wiki/Enabling_Act_of_1802 "Enabling Act of 1802"), authorizing residents of the eastern portion of the Northwest Territory to form the state of Ohio
  * [Missouri Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise "Missouri Compromise"), 1820 federal statute [enabling](/wiki/Enabling_act "Enabling act") the admission of Missouri (a [slave state](/wiki/Slave_and_free_states "Slave and free states")) and Maine (a free state) into the Union
  * [Toledo War](/wiki/Toledo_War "Toledo War"), 1835–36 boundary dispute between Ohio and the adjoining Michigan Territory, which delayed Michigan's admission to the Union
  * [Texas annexation](/wiki/Texas_annexation "Texas annexation"), the 1845 incorporation of the Republic of Texas into the United States as a state in the Union

    

  * [Legal status of Texas](/wiki/Legal_status_of_Texas "Legal status of Texas")

  * [Compromise of 1850](/wiki/Compromise_of_1850 "Compromise of 1850"), a package of congressional acts, one of which provided for the admission of California to the Union
  * [Bleeding Kansas](/wiki/Bleeding_Kansas "Bleeding Kansas"), a series of violent conflicts in Kansas Territory involving [anti-slavery](/wiki/Free-Stater_\(Kansas\) "Free-Stater \(Kansas\)") and [pro-slavery](/wiki/Border_Ruffian "Border Ruffian") factions in the years preceding Kansas statehood, 1854–61
  * [Enabling Act of 1889](/wiki/Enabling_Act_of_1889 "Enabling Act of 1889"), authorizing residents of Dakota, Montana, and Washington territories to form state governments (Dakota to be divided into two states) and to gain admission to the Union
  * [Enabling Act of 1906](/wiki/Oklahoma_Enabling_Act "Oklahoma Enabling Act") authorizing residents of Oklahoma, Indian, New Mexico, and Arizona territories to form state governments (Indian and Oklahoma territories to be combined into one state) and to gain admission to the Union
  * [Alaska Statehood Act](/wiki/Alaska_Statehood_Act "Alaska Statehood Act"), admitting Alaska as a state in the Union as of January 3, 1959

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._states_by_date_of_admission_to_the_Union&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** This list does not account for the [secession](/wiki/Secession "Secession") of 11 states (Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Tennessee, Arkansas, Louisiana, and Texas) during the [Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") to form the [Confederate States of America](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of America"), nor for the subsequent restoration of those states to the Union, or each state's "readmission to representation in Congress" [after the war](/wiki/Reconstruction_Era "Reconstruction Era"), as the federal government does not give legal recognition to their having left the Union. Also, the Constitution is silent on the question of whether states have the power to secede from the Union, but the [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States") held that a state cannot unilaterally do so in _[Texas v. White](/wiki/Texas_v._White "Texas v. White")_ (1869).[7]
  2. **Jump up ^** Also known as the "Three Lower Counties Upon Delaware." Delaware became a state on June 15, 1776, when the Delaware Assembly formally adopted a resolution declaring an end to Delaware's status as a colony of Great Britain and establishing the three counties as an independent state under the authority of "the Government of the Counties of New Castle, Kent and Sussex Upon Delaware."[9]
  3. **Jump up ^** Between 1749 and 1764 the provincial governor of [New Hampshire](/wiki/Province_of_New_Hampshire "Province of New Hampshire"), [Benning Wentworth](/wiki/Benning_Wentworth "Benning Wentworth"), issued approximately 135 grants for unoccupied land claimed by New Hampshire west of the [Connecticut River](/wiki/Connecticut_River "Connecticut River") (in what is today southern Vermont), territory that was also claimed by [New York](/wiki/Province_of_New_York "Province of New York"). The resulting "[New Hampshire Grants](/wiki/New_Hampshire_Grants "New Hampshire Grants")" dispute led to the rise of the [Green Mountain Boys](/wiki/Green_Mountain_Boys "Green Mountain Boys"), and the later establishment of the Vermont Republic. New Hampshire's claim upon the land was extinguished in 1764 by [royal order](/wiki/Order_in_Council "Order in Council") of [George III](/wiki/George_III_of_the_United_Kingdom "George III of the United Kingdom"), and in 1790 the State of New York [ceded](/wiki/Cession "Cession") its land claim to Vermont for 30,000 [Dollars](/wiki/Spanish_dollar "Spanish dollar").
  4. **Jump up ^** The [Virginia General Assembly](/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly "Virginia General Assembly") adopted legislation on December 18, 1789 separating its "District of Kentucky" from the rest of the State and approving its statehood.[17]
  5. **Jump up ^** The exact date upon which Ohio became a state is unclear. On April 30, 1802 the [7th Congress](/wiki/7th_United_States_Congress "7th United States Congress") had passed an [act](/wiki/Act_of_Congress "Act of Congress") "authorizing the inhabitants of Ohio to form a Constitution and state government, and admission of Ohio into the Union." (Sess. 1, ch. 40, 2 [Stat.](/wiki/United_States_Statutes_at_Large "United States Statutes at Large") [173](http://legislink.org/us/stat-2-173)) On February 19, 1803 the same Congress passed an act "providing for the execution of the laws of the United States in the State of Ohio." (Sess. 2, ch. 7, 2 [Stat.](/wiki/United_States_Statutes_at_Large "United States Statutes at Large") [201](http://legislink.org/us/stat-2-201)) Neither act, however, set a formal date of statehood. An official statehood date for Ohio was not set until 1953, when the [83rd Congress](/wiki/83rd_United_States_Congress "83rd United States Congress") passed a [Joint resolution](/wiki/Joint_resolution "Joint resolution") "for admitting the State of Ohio into the Union", ([Pub.L. 83–204](http://legislink.org/us/pl-83-204), 67 [Stat.](/wiki/United_States_Statutes_at_Large "United States Statutes at Large") [407](http://legislink.org/us/stat-67-407), enacted August 7, 1953) which designated March 1, 1803, as that date.[20]
  6. **Jump up ^** The [Massachusetts General Court](/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Court "Massachusetts General Court") passed enabling legislation on June 19, 1819 separating the "District of Maine" from the rest of the State (an action approved by the voters in Maine on July 19, 1819 by 17,001 to 7,132); then, on February 25, 1820, passed a follow-up measure officially accepting the fact of Maine's imminent statehood.[17]
  7. **Jump up ^** On May 13, 1862, the General Assembly of the [Restored Government of Virginia](/wiki/Restored_Government_of_Virginia "Restored Government of Virginia") passed an act granting permission for creation of West Virginia.[34] Later, by its ruling in _[Virginia v. West Virginia](/wiki/Virginia_v._West_Virginia "Virginia v. West Virginia")_ (1871), the Supreme Court implicitly affirmed that the breakaway Virginia counties did have the proper consents necessary to become a separate state.[35]
  8. **Jump up ^** When President [Benjamin Harrison](/wiki/Benjamin_Harrison "Benjamin Harrison") signed the statehood proclamations for North and South Dakota he shuffled the papers on his desk and covered up all but the signature line of the documents. No one knows which state he signed into existence first. North Dakota's proclamation was published first in the _[Statutes at Large](/wiki/United_States_Statutes_at_Large "United States Statutes at Large")_ , as it is first in alphabetical order.[37]
  9. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ Brought into existence within moments of each other on the same day, North and South Dakota are the nation's only twin-born states.
